frameDefinitions: This frame contains words for motions or actions an Agent performs using some part of his/her body.
In this class of perception words, a Phenomenon, typically expressed as External Argument, and its perceptual characteristics are given some description.
This frame contains nouns that refer to sensations in different modalities.
An Agent makes use of a Means (either an action or a (system of) entities standing in for the action) in order to achieve a Purpose.
The words in this frame have to do with non-verbal communication.
frameExamples: Entire platoons have mysteriously <t>vanished</t> from battle, leaving enemy weapons to slice through empty air.
There's a hamburger bar open, and it <t>smells</t> real good.
The huge sand dunes, perpetually changing, make for a surreal <t>sight</t>.
The primary <t>means</t> of gas detection is mass spectroscopy .
I <t>gestured</t> with my hand for him to come over.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> uses some part of his/her body to perform the action. <fen>Agent</fen> occurs as the External Argument.
With some verbs in this frame, the <fen>Body_part</fen> involved in the action is specified by the meaning of the verb and cannot be expressed separately.  For example,
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the body movement occurs.
The location within which the movement of a <fen>Body_part</fen> takes place.
Concrete or abstract entity that does not exist after the event.
This role identifes the Time when a new <fen>Entity</fen> ceases to be.
This is the Place where the new <fen>Entity</fen> ceases to exist.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is typically the External Argument of the verbs in this frame.
<fen>Characterization</fen> is the subjective description (of the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> ) of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Appraisal</fen> is the positive or negative judgement given to the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.

<fen>Inference</fen> expresses some property of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> that is not a direct  feature of the particular sensory modality (if any), but rather is based on perception within that modality.
This role is only expressed with certain nouns in this frame, and then only with the help of a support verb, such as <ment>have</ment>:

This is the entity or phenomenon which gives rise to the sensation. In cases of veridical sensation, this role is not typically distinguished from <fen>Percept</fen>. Most of the phrases that express this role can be paraphrased as <ment>from</ment>-phrases, e.g.

The role <fen>Percept</fen> is used for phrases that express the characteristic property of a sensation. Typically this characteristic property is described with reference to the entity or phenomenon that produces the sensation---that  is why this role can be difficult to distinguish from Source. It is possible for Source and Percept to be expressed separately, however:

This role is assigned to phrases expressing the body part in which a sensation is located. Since touch is the least localized of sense modalities, words relating to haptic sensations are the ones most likely to occur with this FE:
This role is the perceptual background against which the Phenomenon is experienced by the Perceiver.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the sensation is perceived.
The Agent uses the Means to acheive a Purpose.
The action performed by the Agent.
The goal or purpose of the Agent.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> uses the <fen>Means</fen>.
This is the sentient entity that communicates a Message non-verbally. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Communicator'>The teacher</fex> <t>gestured</t> us into the room.

This is the person to whom a non-verbal Message is communicated. It may be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>us</fex> into the room. The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to us</fex> to enter the room.

This is the content of non-verbal communication. It may be expressed as a <ment>that</ment>-clause Complement, a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP Complement, or a directional PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Message'>that it was time to leave</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> to us <fex name='Message'>to enter the room</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> us <fex name='Message'>into the room</fex>.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific body part of the <fen>Communicator</fen> which gestures.
The <fen>Indicated_entity</fen> is the entity which the <fen>Communicator</fen> is pointing out to the <fen>Addressee</fen> as meaningful.
When the gesturing occus.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the gesturing occurs.
listRoleExamples: There was singing for joy in the streets, and <fex>everywhere</fex> people lifting their arms into the air.
Kim's new furniture looks <fex>sort of bluish</fex>.
Pat sounds <fex>devastated</fex> by the bad news.
<fex>I</fex> have a tingling sensation in my hands.
The smell <fex>of the garlic</fex> made me hungry.
This herb gives off a smell <fex>of garlic</fex>.
I have a tingling feeling <fex>in my hands</fex>.
